author: Special Correspondent
text:
Taking suo motu cognisance of media reports on the suicide of a farmer from Cuddalore district, who was reportedly insulted by a private bank and beaten up by police for loan default, the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) has issued a notice to the State government calling for reports within two weeks.

According to media reports, officials of a private finance firm seized his tractor, abused and insulted him for not repaying Rs.2 lakh.

“The Commission has observed that the contents of the news reports, if true, raise a serious issue of violation of human rights of farmers in Tamil Nadu. Accordingly, notices have been issued to the Chief Secretary, Government of Tamil Nadu, calling for a factual report within two weeks,” an official release stated.

Arumugam from Orathur in the district had taken a loan of Rs.7 lakh from the firm for purchasing a tractor and repaid Rs.5 lakh.

Following the treatment meted out to him by bank officials and the police, he reportedly consumed poison and later died at Primary Health Centre in Keezhapavur, the release stated.

This is the second case in less than a week relating to torture on indebted farmers in Tamil Nadu.

It may be recalled that last week, the NHRC had taken suo motu cognisance of media reports alleging beating of a farmer in Thanjavur district by police and the private bank officials over non-payment of loan.

The Commission totally disapproved of forcible recovery. Torture and brutal attack for recovery of loans amount to serious violation of human rights, it added.
title: NHRC seeks report on farmer’s suicide
